intro: Jacquinia berteroi subsp. acutifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaved jacquinia, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often in mountainous regions, and prefers partial to full sun exposure. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a distinctive acuminate tip, giving it its subspecies name. It produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, blooming in late spring to early summer.
